Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2009 05:51PM Jean09 wrote: Hi Sammy, Glad to hear you were seen today.  Were you seen by an oncologist?  If not, I would contact your oncologist office and let them know what is going on.  Since you are out of town, maybe they can refer you to an oncologist in your area.  What is happening to you does not sound good.
Posts.Title: I"m on TCx6 and HIVES have hit me! sammygrey44 sammygrey44

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2009 01:49PM Jean09 wrote: Hi Ladies, I wish all the oncologists would get together for on BIG meeting about treating their patients.  So they will all be on the same page.  My onc told me it was ok to take vitamin C during chemo, it helps boost the immune system.  And I was told to avoid soy, as much as I can.  You can't avoid it totally, just dont start overloading on it.  Also, I've read that people who live in countries that eat alot of soy have eaten soy all their life so their body is used to it.  We americans have not had a soy based diet all of our lives like other countries.  So when diagnosed with ER+ breast cancer it is NOT a good thing to suddenly put tons of soy into our bodies.
Posts.Title: No soy? kimber3006 kimber3006

Posts.Content: May 11, 2009 06:56PM Jean09 wrote: Hello Everyone,  This is all new to me and I'm so thankful I found this website that can give so much hope, inspiration and advice while on this journey.  I was diagnosed in April and started chemo on May 5th.  I am receiving TC.  So far, side effects have been fatigue and bone/muscle aches and stomach cramps when I go to the bathroom.  I dont have a problem with constipation, just these darn cramps, is this normal?   Reading through some of the postings, I noticed alot of women work while going through this, my onc currently has me on disability until October, 2009.  Is anyone else out there on disability while going through this?  I would not be able to function work wise while going through this so hats off to those who are working!!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo April 2009 tulipbebe MissouriCatLady

Posts.Content: May 13, 2009 04:59AM Jean09 wrote: Hi BC Friends, Bombus, I'll keep you in my prayers that things go well for you on round three, hang in there.  DBOak - I have a rash also but mine are tiny bumps that itch like crazy.  I went in for a blood draw yesterday and they said to put benadryl on them to relieve the itch.  I hope this works and it doesnt get worse.  My WBC's are critical low and I have to stay indoors, no access to public.  I am going to go stir crazy, luckily I found this site and all of you ladies!  Has anyone else been told by their onc that the treatment will cure you of the cancer?
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo April 2009 tulipbebe MissouriCatLady

I know the cost of chemo treatments and that Neulasta shot are out of this world.  I feel bad for those that are diagnosed without insurance.....

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2009 10:56AM Jean09 wrote: Hi Rose, I am just having some anxiety of this and just want to be sure this is the right thing for me.  A blood test in September (after chemo completed) showed I was menopause.  I am 47 years old.  Is there any way that I this could be reversed, to go from menopause to non menopause?   I was having alot of hot flashes during chemo but now I rarely have a hot flash.  If I do, it's usually at night when I go to bed and they are mild hot flashes.  I'm concerned that I'm no longer in menopause....am I crazy or can this happen???

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2009 11:19AM Jean09 wrote: I check for lumps/bumps everyday also.  However on my right breast where I had the surgeries, I cant tell if the lump/bump is scar tissue or something else.  This is something I'll discuss with my surgeon during the next visit. I'm also a bit confused about the location of the node they removed that was positive.  I just assumed it was from the armpit area.  My rad onc said they were radiating on my upper chest due to the positive node.  The redness from radiation is up near my neck, collarbone area.  Something else I'll need to discuss with the surgeon as I did not ask questions in the beginning.  This whole experience has been one big learning process for me.  It's great to have other women to talk to who are going through or have gone through the same thing!!
Posts.Title: Stage II Forum rumoret NativeMainer

Posts.Content: Jean09 wrote: Hi Ladies, I have completed chemo and radiation treatment for stage 2a, er/pr positive breast cancer.  My oncologist is going to start me on arimidex to deter recurrence.  Chemo treatments put me in menopause, I had hot flashes like crazy during treatment.  Now that chemo is done, I have less hot flashes, about one or two a day (usually in the evening).  My question is, would removing my ovaries give me a better chance that the cancer will not come back since I have a very high percentage of estrogen positive?  I want to do everything I can to keep this beast from coming back and I'll do it if it will give me better odds.  What are the advantages, disadvantages of having them removed?   I am 47 years old and cannot have anymore children due to a hysterectomy at age 35.  I prefer to have them removed but would like to know what the side effects wll be. Thoughts? Thank you in advance for your advice on this issue. Dx 4/2009, IDC, 1cm, Stage IIA, Grade 2, 1/6 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Remove ovaries after treatment, Yes or No? Jean09 Jean09

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2009 06:49AM - edited Oct 31, 2009 07:25AM by Jean09
Posts.Title: Remove ovaries after treatment, Yes or No? Jean09 Jean09

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2009 05:36AM Jean09 wrote: Hi Mary, I did not have genetic testing done.  BC does not run in my family.  My BS said that since bc does not run in my family and my estrogen was such a high percentage, genetic testing was not for me.  My onc said my high estrogen level is what caused my cancer and because of this I have a high success rate of beating it with treatment.  Estrogen is what was "feeding" my cancer.  He said along with treatment I need to lose weight and watch what I eat (no soy).  I just feel removing ovaries will get rid of the estrogen and give me a much better chance.  This is something I'll discuss with my onc on my next visit.  I was just wondering what the side effects will be.  I've already been through so much, I just want to get my life back to normal as much as possible without anymore side effects!!
Posts.Title: Remove ovaries after treatment, Yes or No? Jean09 Jean09
